video_description: A video review of the Asus Eee Slate EP121 Windows 7 tablet. Check out our full review at: http://www.mobiletechreview.com/notebooks/Asus-Eee-Slate.htm The Eee Slate runs Windows 7 Home Premium 64 bit on a ULV Intel Core i5 CPU. It has a 12.1" AFFS display that's similar to IPS but has better outdoor viewing. The 12.1" size hits the sweet spot for capacitive touch and the tablet has a Wacom digitizer for pen input and drawing/painting. The Asus is a very powerful tablet that's designed for both content creation and consumption and is perfect for artists and those who need to use Windows apps on their tablet.
title: Asus Eee Slate EP121 Review

comments.text: Please don't buy this for painting, it's noticeably laggy... If you want to paint, do it at home/work on a good Mac/PC with a Wacom Intuos4 or Cintiq. Win7 and OS﻿ X are not built for tablets and are annoying at best. Only iOS works well so far and Android is catching up, but way too slowly.
comments.author: intelligentlight

comments.text: You're joking right? The ASUS Eee Slate is awesome for painting! Photoshop, Illustrator, Painter all work really well, and I'm even﻿ sculpting in ZBrush without lag. It's obviously not as powerful as my 12 core desktop, but then no laptop is, you would have to be a moron to think otherwise. But this thing smokes any other tablet. Have you even used the EP121 yet?
comments.author: TheOnlyKingArthur

comments.text: Nope, I would only buy this﻿ product for doodling in Sketchbook Pro on the train on the way to work. Nothing else. The screen is too small and Win7 is not a proper tablet OS. You see it every time she clicks in this video. I have tried it and what I meant was for serious painting get a real wacom tablet or wacom cintiq screen. Zbrush in 12" is a funny joke, you need a 24" for the tiny detailed interface and another 24" next to it with the reference photos. No thanks... :)
comments.author: intelligentlight

comments.text: Please note that I am not saying that it doesn't smokes the competition. :) It does. I like where this technology is going, but for my train ride﻿ I will stick with the iPad 2 and then do the real work on my 12-core at work - like you. Have you tried a Cintiq 21UX btw? I would LUV one of those.
comments.author: intelligentlight

comments.text: You can't knock something until you try it. :-) I was pretty skeptical about the 12" screen size, but it is actually really nice! It is almost the exact same size as a standard piece of paper, which most people write﻿ and draw on more ofter than any other size. I tried ZBrush out of curiosity more than expectation and you have to see how well it performs! I will post a performance video next week. I do like the Wacom Cintiq screens and you know they make a 12" model right?
comments.author: TheOnlyKingArthur

comments.text: Sounds good. :) Yeah, the Cintiq comes in 12" and 21" flavors. I currently use an Intuos 4 with Photoshop, Maya, Mudbox, Zbrush, Lightroom and Sketchbook Pro at work and loving it. But then again, I upgraded from a Bamboo Medium. :)﻿
comments.author: intelligentlight

comments.text: We had a full﻿ lab of 21" Cintiq monitors at The Art Institute, but since I graduated I no longer have access to them :-( I loved using them when I could though. I have an Intuos4 with an airbrush pen at work and an Intuos3 at home. I use most of the same software as well, but there is a disconnect that you will always get between a separate monitor and Wacom tablet. You get used to it, but it's never as good as a Cintiq or this new tablet which I am really enjoying.
comments.author: TheOnlyKingArthur

comments.text: Too bad. Yeah, I wish that I had one. I luv the Intuos4 but of course﻿ it's not the same as painting on top of the screen like the amazing Cintiqs. Hopefully these tablets (above and next gens) will push the limits and also perhaps lower the prices of the Wacom products - so most people can afford to paint on screens... :)

comments.text: Is not a SSD another type of hard drive ? ,﻿ or is it a soft-drive? A hard-disk has spinning disk , a drive might have not disk's.
comments.author: roffpoff

comments.text:
An HDD has platters that store data﻿ and spin around, meaning it is a mechanical drive, which is a drive with moving parts.

A Solid State Drive has no moving parts, and stores it's memory on microchips.

comments.text:
It all depends on computing style and needs.

This Asus product is similar to the HP Pavilion tx2000 series, and it's designed for somebody that's either a hard-gamer or has to interact in a regular basis with heavy applications such Photoshop, Autodesk, and the like. One of the CONS for this is that it runs on Windows 7 and application controls and tabs end up﻿ being to small to click and with time it'll get on your nerves. For a designer this tablet is more of a showcase equipment.
comments.author: blakchile

comments.text:
If you're looking for a tablet to surf the web, read ebooks, on-the-fly editing﻿ of Office files, light gaming, media viewing, the  ASUS Transformer Pad TF300T or the TF300TG(3G capability) would be a better option if you need to be hooked up 24/7 to social networks (facebook, twitter, etc.). 

A smartphone would be a good choice if you don't mind a small screen and small-letter reading, but it won't provide the benefits of a tablet for easier and faster typing, multi-tasking, etc.
comments.author: blakchile

comments.text: I want to get this tablet but I`m little worried about the battery life because the﻿ battery lasts 2-3 hours. It will be recharged 2,3 times a day and that can`t be good for the battery (talking from my experience with laptops).
comments.author: Saso Stoilevski

comments.text: Saso - don't let the battery life stop you, I just bought one. The back comes off fairly easy and the batteries are readily available online and they just plug in to the main board, so replacement is very easy. They have come down a bit in price too so now is a good time﻿ to get one. Have a good night.

comments.text: Hi Lisa, I love your reviews and am subscribed. I am not sure if someone had already ask you this, but I just bought one of this and it runs pretty hot in the back. I couldn't keep it on my lap for after about 10 to 20 minutes. I used it without the folio case. I used speedfan program and it checked at about 58 Celsius﻿ when playing two youtube videos at 1080p within the youtube site. Is this normal or I got a bad piece of product? Thanks and everyone's welcome to reply with their experienced.
